paragraphs.text: Give up the caffeine and see what happens. To avoid withdrawal headaches — which are mostly placebo — replace your caffeine with something else (another placebo). After a few days without caffeine, you’ll develop confidence in your ability to function without it.

Ordinary people seek entertainment. Extraordinary people seek educationand learning. It is common for the world’s most successful people to read at least one book per week. They are constantly learning.

paragraphs.text: I can easily get through one audiobook per week by just listening during my commute to school and while walking on campus. Taking even 15–30 minutes every morning to read uplifting and instructive information changes you. It puts you in the zone to perform at your highest.

paragraphs.name: 452d
paragraphs.text: Although people think they perform better on caffeine, the truth is, they really don’t. Actually, we’ve become so dependent on caffeine that we use it to simply get back to our status-quo. When we’re off it, we under perform and become incapable.

paragraphs.name: a5ea
paragraphs.text: Shouldn’t there be room for both? Especially if that’s the way one chooses? I can see the motivational value in an educational book at the beginning of the day, but why not a chapter of an entertaining book at the end of the day to aid relaxation, and ready one for sleep?

71acfdbe9d12.title: As an atheist, this pricks me (even more than the entry about prayer).

paragraphs.text: As an atheist, this pricks me (even more than the entry about prayer). While I can understand “praying” (I meditate and incorporate some declarations about my day/intentions), having faith is a tough phrase to accept. I think there is something here though. It makes a statement about what I can do, what dreams I can accomplish. Without faith, my…

paragraphs.name: a545
paragraphs.text: That’s because people who feel they need to make their bed suffer from some level of compulsion which indulged in will make them feel better. Less compulsive people are not weighed down with the little things they have not done.

e7687a8a3f8b.title: Ben Hardy, always and consistently, gives a fantastic amount of good advice.

paragraphs.name: 1b67
paragraphs.text: Ben Hardy, always and consistently, gives a fantastic amount of good advice. But unfortunately some kind of reference to prayer or faith or spirituality always creeps in, with apparent justification. I realise he can’t help his cultural background, and much of the USA is, like the Arab world, mentally stuck in the 15th century. But it’s a bit weird…
